mpiea_mmr package¶

Submodules¶

mpiea_mmr.blender_utils module¶

Utilities for interaction with Blender

class mpiea_mmr.blender_utils.ArgumentParserForBlender(prog=None, usage=None, description=None, epilog=None, parents=[], formatter_class=<class 'argparse.HelpFormatter'>, prefix_chars='-', fromfile_prefix_chars=None, argument_default=None, conflict_handler='error', add_help=True, allow_abbrev=True)[source]¶

Bases: argparse.ArgumentParser

This class is identical to its superclass, except for the parse_args method (see docstring). It resolves the ambiguity generated when calling Blender from the CLI with a python script, and both Blender and the script have arguments. E.g., the following call will make Blender crash because it will try to process the script’s -a and -b flags:

blender --python my_script.py -a 1 -b 2

To bypass this issue this class uses the fact that Blender will ignore all arguments given after a double-dash (‘–’). The approach is that all arguments before ‘–’ go to Blender, arguments after go to the script. The following CLI calls work fine:

blender --python my_script.py -- -a 1 -b 2
blender --python my_script.py --
get_argv_after_doubledash(argv)[source]¶
Parameters:argv (list<str>) – Expected to be sys.argv (or alike).
Returns:The argv sublist after the first '--' element (if present, otherwise returns an empty list).
Return type:list of str

Note

Works with any ordered collection of strings (e.g. list, tuple).

parse_args()[source]¶

This method is expected to behave identically as in the superclass, except that the sys.argv list will be pre-processed using get_argv_after_doubledash before. See the docstring of the class for usage examples and details.

Note

By default, argparse.ArgumentParser will call sys.exit() when encountering an error. Blender will react to that shutting down, making it look like a crash. Make sure the arguments are correct!

class mpiea_mmr.blender_utils.KeymapManager[source]¶

Bases: list

This class implements functionality for registering/deregistering keymaps into Blender. It also behaves like a regular list, holding the keymaps currently registered. To inspect the registered keymaps simply iterate the instance.

KEYMAP_NAME = 'Object Mode'¶
KEYMAP_SPACE_TYPE = 'EMPTY'¶
register(context, key, stroke_mode, op_name, ctrl=True, shift=True, alt=False)[source]¶

Adds a new keymap to this collection, and to the config in context.window_manager.keyconfigs.addon. See the API for details:

https://docs.blender.org/api/blender2.8/bpy.types.KeyMap.html
https://docs.blender.org/api/blender2.8/bpy.types.KeyMapItem.html
https://docs.blender.org/manual/de/dev/advanced/keymap_editing.html

Usage example:

kmm = KeymapManager()
kmm.register(bpy.context, "D", "PRESS", MyOperator.bl_idname)
Parameters:
  • context (bpy.types.Context) – The Blender context to work in.
  • key (str) – See bpy.types.KeyMapItem.key_modifier
  • stroke_mode (str) – See bpy.types.KeyMapItem.value
  • op_name (str) – Name of a valid operation in bpy.ops (usually the bl_idname)
  • ctrl, shift, alt (booleans) – Modifiers of the key
Returns:

None
unregister()[source]¶

Removes every mapped item from every keymap in this collection, and then empties the collection.

class mpiea_mmr.blender_utils.OperatorToMenuManager[source]¶

Bases: list

This class implements functionality for adding/removing operators into Blender UI menus. It also behaves like a regular list, holding the currently registered items. Usage example:

omm = OperatorToMenuManager()
# In register():
omm.register(MyOperator, bpy.types.VIEW3D_MT_object)
# ... in unregister():
omm.unregister
register(op_class, menu_class)[source]¶
Parameters:
  • op_class (bpy.types.Operator) – (Sub)class handle with desired functionality.
  • menu_class (bpy.types.{Header, Panel, ..}) – Class handle for the Blender GUI where the functionality can be triggered.

Note

op_class must define the bl_idname and bl_label fields.

unregister()[source]¶

Removes every mapped operator from every menu class in this collection, then empties the collection.

class mpiea_mmr.blender_utils.PurgeUnusedData[source]¶

Bases: object

Blender objects point to data. E.g., a lamp points to a given data lamp object. Removing the objects doesn’t remove the data, which may lead to data blocks that aren’t being used by anyone. Given a collection of categories returned by the get_categories method, this function removes all datablocks with zero users. .. note:

The order of the given categories may affect the result (e.g.
deleting some parent data before the children may be problematic.
See https://blender.stackexchange.com/a/102046

Note

The categories have to be returned by a method at runtime, since at the time of registering bpy.data is not accessible and won’t compile.

get_categories()[source]¶
Returns:A list of bpy.data.* categories like bpy.data.meshes.
mpiea_mmr.blender_utils.add_cam(context, cam_name, cam_loc, cam_rot, light_name='CamLight', light_loc=Vector((0.0, 1.0, 0.0)), light_watts=40.0, light_shadow=False)[source]¶

Adds a camera object (and optionally a point light attached to it) to the given context, with the given features.

Parameters:
  • context (bpy.types.Context) – The Blender context to work in.
  • cam_name (str) – The desired name for the object and its corresponding data block. Note that if not unique, Blender will append a number.
  • cam_loc (Vector) – The mathutils.Vector(x,y,z) initial location.
  • cam_rot (Euler) – The mathutils.Euler initial rotation.
  • light_name (str) – (Optional). The desired name for the object and its corresponding data block. Note that if not unique, Blender will append a number.
  • light_loc (Vector) – (Optional). The mathutils.Vector(x,y,z) initial location.
  • light_rot (Euler) – (Optional). The mathutils.Euler initial rotation.
  • light_watts (float) – (Optional). Cam light intensity in Watts.
  • light_shadow (bool) – (Optional).Whether the cam light causes shadows.
Returns:

None

Note

The camera light is optional. If any of the light_* parameters is None, it won’t be added.

mpiea_mmr.blender_utils.add_floor(context, name, size, metallic=0.0, specular=0.0, roughness=1.0, subsurf_ratio=0.0, subsurf_color=Vector((1.0, 1.0, 1.0, 1.0)), texture_img_abspath=None, texture_img_tilesize=1.0)[source]¶

Adds a square mesh at zero height,(representing the floor) to the given context, with the given features. It adds a colored subsurface to the mesh, as well as some “material” options, and optionally a texture from an image.

Parameters:
  • name (str) – The desired name for the object and its corresponding data block. Note that if not unique, Blender will append a number.
  • size (float) – Side length of the square, in meters.
  • metallic (float) – From 0 (not metallic) to 1 (fully metallic).
  • specular (float) – From 0 (not specular) to 1 (fully specular).
  • specular – From 0 (not rough) to 1 (fully rough).
  • subsurf_ratio (float) – Subsurface mix, from 0 (no subsurface) to 1.
  • subsurf_color (mathutils.Vector) – 4-dimensional float RGBA with values from 0 (black/transparent) to 1 (full color/opaque).
  • texture_img_abspath (str) – (Optional), absolute path to an image to load as tiled texture onto the plane.
  • texture_img_tilesize (float) – (Optional), positive float. The size ratio for the tiled image texture: the bigger this number, the bigger the tiles on the plane will be.
Returns:

None

Note

The texture image is optional. If any of the texture_* parameters is None, it won’t be added.

mpiea_mmr.blender_utils.add_sun(context, sun_name, sun_loc, sun_rot, sun_strength)[source]¶

Adds a sun object to the given context, with the given features.

Parameters:
  • context (bpy.types.Context) – The Blender context to work in.
  • sun_name (str) – The desired name for the object and its corresponding data block. Note that if not unique, Blender will append a number.
  • sun_loc (Vector) – The mathutils.Vector(x,y,z) initial location.
  • sun_rot (Euler) – The mathutils.Euler initial rotation.
  • sun_strength (float) – light intensity relative a reference sun (i.e. 1.0 means “one sun” of intensity).
Returns:

None
mpiea_mmr.blender_utils.asset_path(*path_elements)[source]¶

A convenience path wrapper to find assets in this repository. Retrieves the absolute path, given the OS-agnostic path relative to the package root path (by bysically joining the path elements via os.path.join). E.g., the following call retrieves the absolute path for <PACKAGE_ROOT>/a/b/test.txt:

asset_path("a", "b", "test.txt")
Params strings path_elements:
 From left to right, the path nodes, the last one being the filename.
Return type:str
mpiea_mmr.blender_utils.deselect_by_name(*names)[source]¶

Given a variable number of names as strings, tries to select all existing objects in D.objects by their name.

If the given context contains an area of the given area_type, returns the area. Otherwise returns None

mpiea_mmr.blender_utils.set_render_resolution_percentage(p=100)[source]¶
mpiea_mmr.blender_utils.set_shading_mode(mode='SOLID', screens=[])[source]¶

Performs an action analogous to clicking on the display/shade button of the 3D view. Mode is one of “RENDERED”, “MATERIAL”, “SOLID”, “WIREFRAME”. The change is applied to the given collection of bpy.data.screens. If none is given, the function is applied to bpy.context.screen (the active screen) only. E.g. set all screens to rendered mode:

set_shading_mode("RENDERED", D.screens)

mpiea_mmr.operators module¶

This module contains ubclasses from bpy.types.Operator defining user-callable functors. Operators can also be embedded in Panels and other UI elements.

class mpiea_mmr.operators.AbstractMaximizeArea[source]¶

Bases: object

If the current context has an area of type self.AREA_TYPE, that area gets maximized. Otherwise does nothing. Supported types can be seen here:

.. warning::
This is an abstract class. It is not expected to be directly used. Instead, extend it before as shown.

To create an Operator for a specific area type, simply extend this class as follows:

class MaximizeAreaView3d(Operator, AbstractMaximizeArea):
    AREA_TYPE = "VIEW_3D"
    bl_idname = "screen.maximize_view_3d"  # path after 'bpy.ops'
    bl_label = "Maximize VIEW_3D (if present)"
Supported types can be seen here:
https://docs.blender.org/api/blender2.8/bpy.types.Area.html
execute(context)[source]¶

See class docstring.

classmethod poll(context)[source]¶

Predicate, True iff context.screen.areas contains an area of self.AREA_TYPE

mpiea_mmr.ui module¶

This module contains the functionality related to user-interaction (UI) with Blender, i.e.:

  • Subclasses from bpy.types.Operator defining user-callable functors.
  • Subclasses from bpy.types.Panel that contain GUI widgets and functionality.

class mpiea_mmr.ui.MpieaMmrPanel[source]¶

Bases: object

Mix-in to be inherited by every Panel that belongs to the ‘MPIEA MultiModalRenderer’ tab, to avoid verbosity and potential inconsistencies.

Attributes:

bl_category
The tab name. Blender will place the Panel in the tab given by its bl_category (i.e. all Panels extending this class will belong to the same tab).
bl_space_type
The tab will show up in the specified space (e.g. TEXT_EDITOR, IMAGE_EDITOR, VIEW_3D). If the tab is desired in multiple spaces, multiple classes have to be defined, each with their respective bl_space_type.
bl_region_type
Value set to UI, alternatives not known.

Note

Whether a Panel appears in a tab or not, and the ordering among panels is specified in the register() function (by simply registering all the desired panels in order).

bl_category = 'MPIEA MultiModalRenderer'¶
bl_region_type = 'UI'¶
bl_space_type = 'VIEW_3D'¶
classmethod poll(context)[source]¶

Dummy implementation, returns True always.

Module contents¶

Init file for the add-on.

To install it, make sure Blender’s Python is able to find it under addon_utils.paths(), and that the Blender version matches to make it installable.

Alternatively, run this init file as a script from Blender.

mpiea_mmr.register()[source]¶

Main register function, called on startup by Blender

mpiea_mmr.unregister()[source]¶

Main unregister function, called on shutdown by Blender
